articles.headline: U.S. Satellite Plans Falter, Imperiling Data on Storms
articles.snippet: A year or more without key satellites could result in shaky forecasts about storms like Hurricane Sandy.
articles.abstract: A year or more without key satellites could result in shaky forecasts about storms like Hurricane Sandy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is facing a year or more without crucial satellites that provide invaluable data for predicting storm tracks, a result of years of mismanagement, lack of financing and delays in launching replacements, according to several recent official reviews.

articles.headline: 总理家人隐秘的财富
articles.snippet: This is a Chinese-language version of an investigation by The New York Times showing that the family of Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, who has staked a position as a populist and a reformer, owns about $2.7 billion in assets.
articles.abstract: This is a Chinese-language version of an investigation by The New York Times showing that the family of Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, who has staked a position as a populist and a reformer, owns about $2.7 billion in assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a Chinese-language version of an investigation by The New York Times showing that the family of Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, who has staked a position as a populist and a reformer, owns about $2.7 billion in assets.

articles.headline: The Art World, Blurred
articles.snippet: The art world is seeing less distinct boundaries in how institutions like auction houses and galleries operate.
articles.abstract: The art world is seeing less distinct boundaries in how institutions like auction houses and galleries operate.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCKED on the south side of Sotheby’s second floor is an all-white space that might as well be a gallery in the heart of Chelsea. Designed by Richard Gluckman, the New York architect who created Chelsea art galleries for dealers like Paula Cooper, Mary Boone and Larry Gagosian, this year-old space, called S2, is what officials at the auction house refer to as its “selling exhibition gallery.”

articles.headline: What Medicare Will Cover Even if You’re Not Likely to Get Better
articles.snippet: A proposed settlement would open up payment for more therapies for people with conditions like Alzheimer’s disease, multiple sclerosis and Parkinson’s disease.
articles.abstract: A proposed settlement would open up payment for more therapies for people with conditions like Alzheimer’s disease, multiple sclerosis and Parkinson’s disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should the federal government cover the costs of many kinds of treatments for patients who aren’t going to get any better?

articles.headline: U.S. Cuts Estimate of Sugar Intake
articles.snippet: The Agriculture Department has lowered its estimate of annual sugar consumption to around 80 pounds a person from nearly 100 pounds, reshaping the debate over sweeteners.
articles.abstract: The Agriculture Department has lowered its estimate of annual sugar consumption to around 80 pounds a person from nearly 100 pounds, reshaping the debate over sweeteners.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was repeated so often it was accepted as true: the typical American consumed 95 to 100 pounds of sugar each year. Health experts said that consumption was surely contributing to a nationwide crisis of obesity.

articles.headline: Playing Hardball Runs in the Family
articles.snippet: Named after his great grandfather, a Hall of Fame baseball manager, Representative Connie Mack IV has a recognizable name, but that doesn’t always work in his favor.
articles.abstract: Named after his great grandfather, a Hall of Fame baseball manager, Representative Connie Mack IV has a recognizable name, but that doesn’t always work in his favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

articles.headline: In Virginia, Romney Scours Coal Country for Edge Over Obama
articles.snippet: The anger of southwest Virginia coal miners at the Obama administration is providing an opening for Mitt Romney’s campaign.
articles.abstract: The anger of southwest Virginia coal miners at the Obama administration is providing an opening for Mitt Romney’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jay Swiney emerges from the night shift in the coal mines to assume his duties as mayor of Appalachia, Va., it is hard for him to miss the partisan forces rocking the heavily unionized Democratic hamlets in the mountains along the Tennessee border.

articles.headline: Here’s a Memo From the Boss: Vote This Way
articles.snippet: Freed to do so by the Supreme Court, major companies are suggesting and sometimes explicitly recommending how their workers should vote this fall.
articles.abstract: Freed to do so by the Supreme Court, major companies are suggesting and sometimes explicitly recommending how their workers should vote this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine getting a letter from the boss, telling you how to vote.

articles.headline: Mutual Fund Leaders Aim to End Jam Over Rules
articles.snippet: Worried about a regulatory crackdown, mutual fund executives are pushing for limited restrictions on a controversial type of fund in an effort to end a dispute with the government.
articles.abstract: Worried about a regulatory crackdown, mutual fund executives are pushing for limited restrictions on a controversial type of fund in an effort to end a dispute with the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worried about a regulatory crackdown, mutual fund executives are pushing for limited restrictions on a controversial type of fund in an effort to end a bitter dispute between the government and the financial industry.

articles.headline: Rise in Household Debt Might Be Sign of a Strengthening Recovery
articles.snippet: In a shift, Americans are taking on more debt than they are shedding, indicating that a more resilient recovery is on the way.
articles.abstract: In a shift, Americans are taking on more debt than they are shedding, indicating that a more resilient recovery is on the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time since the Great Recession hit, American households are taking on more debt than they are shedding, an epochal shift that might augur a more resilient recovery.

articles.headline: Reports on Energy Drinks Show Gaps in Safety Policy
articles.snippet: While the Food and Drug Administration regularly makes reports about drugs and medical devices public, it does not do so for dietary supplements like energy drinks.
articles.abstract: While the Food and Drug Administration regularly makes reports about drugs and medical devices public, it does not do so for dietary supplements like energy drinks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The disclosure this week that the deaths of five people since 2009 may be linked to a popular energy drink has revealed major gaps in the way federal regulators and companies monitor product safety.

articles.headline: In Dairy Industry Consolidation, Lush Paydays
articles.snippet: Through certain deals, huge paychecks went to a small group of people, including the chief executive of Dean Foods and a former head of a dairy cooperative.
articles.abstract: Through certain deals, huge paychecks went to a small group of people, including the chief executive of Dean Foods and a former head of a dairy cooperative.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time not long ago when Gregg L. Engles was considered a genius in the dairy industry, a shrewd C.E.O. who had cobbled together a string of local businesses to create the nation’s largest milk bottler, Dean Foods.

articles.headline: In Final Days of the Race, Fighting County by County
articles.snippet: The fight for the White House is being waged on intensely local terrain, in places whose voting histories and demographics have been studied in minute detail by both sides.
articles.abstract: The fight for the White House is being waged on intensely local terrain, in places whose voting histories and demographics have been studied in minute detail by both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — President Obama and Mitt Romney are plunging into the final nine days of a multibillion-dollar presidential race focused not only on the seven most competitive states, but also on battleground counties within them that could tip the balance of an exceedingly close contest.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: The Perils of Feeding a Bloated Industry
articles.snippet: Powerful new research looks into reasons for the financial sector’s vast growth before the financial crisis — and at the social impact.
articles.abstract: Powerful new research looks into reasons for the financial sector’s vast growth before the financial crisis — and at the social impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: THEY say the wheels of justice grind slowly, but should it really have taken more than five years for the Justice Department to discover that Countrywide Financial, the mortgage mania’s top creator of risky loans, dumped a load of that junk on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac?

articles.headline: From Calm Leadership, Lasting Change
articles.snippet: Rachel Carson, who warned of pesticides’ toll on nature in “Silent Spring” 50 years ago, offered an indelible example of the power of individual action.
articles.abstract: Rachel Carson, who warned of pesticides’ toll on nature in “Silent Spring” 50 years ago, offered an indelible example of the power of individual action.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHE was a slight, soft-spoken woman who preferred walking the Maine shoreline to stalking the corridors of power. And yet Rachel Carson, the author of “Silent Spring,” played a central role in starting the environmental movement, by forcing government and business to confront the dangers of pesticides.

articles.headline: A Part-Time Life, as Hours Shrink and Shift
articles.snippet: Retailers are relying on part-time workers, a trend that has frustrated millions of Americans who want full-time jobs but must instead settle for reduced pay and benefits.
articles.abstract: Retailers are relying on part-time workers, a trend that has frustrated millions of Americans who want full-time jobs but must instead settle for reduced pay and benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRING VALLEY, Calif. — Since the Fresh & Easy grocery chain was founded five years ago, it has opened 150 stores in California and positioned itself as a hip, socially responsible company.

articles.headline: Iraqi Sects Join Battle in Syria on Both Sides
articles.snippet: Many Iraqi Sunnis and Shiites see the Syrian war as a religious conflict and are joining the battle, driving Syria ever closer to becoming a regional sectarian battlefield.
articles.abstract: Many Iraqi Sunnis and Shiites see the Syrian war as a religious conflict and are joining the battle, driving Syria ever closer to becoming a regional sectarian battlefield.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Militant Sunnis from Iraq have been going to Syria to fight against President Bashar al-Assad for months. Now Iraqi Shiites are joining the battle in increasing numbers, but on the government’s side, transplanting Iraq’s explosive sectarian conflict to a civil war that is increasingly fueled by religious rivalry.
articles.byline: By Yasir Ghazi and Tim Arango

articles.headline: A Village Rape Shatters a Family, and India’s Traditional Silence
articles.snippet: An outcry over a string of recent rapes has focused national attention on India’s rising number of sexual assaults and exposed the male-dominated power structure in Haryana.
articles.abstract: An outcry over a string of recent rapes has focused national attention on India’s rising number of sexual assaults and exposed the male-dominated power structure in Haryana.
articles.lead_paragraph: DABRA, India — One after the other, the men raped her. They had dragged the girl into a darkened stone shelter at the edge of the fields, eight men, maybe more, reeking of pesticide and cheap whiskey. They assaulted her for nearly three hours. She was 16 years old.

articles.headline: A Troubleshooting ‘Wingman’ Plotting Romney’s Trajectory
articles.snippet: Bob White, an in-house consultant for Mitt Romney’s campaign, has helped steady a wobbly candidacy in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: Bob White, an in-house consultant for Mitt Romney’s campaign, has helped steady a wobbly candidacy in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Mitt Romney’s record at Bain Capital first came under assault, his beleaguered campaign staff turned to Bob White, an informal adviser. He quickly recruited researchers to conduct a deal-by-deal autopsy, searching for uplifting examples to share with voters to counter rivals’ accounts of exploitative ones.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Arrest of ’70s Rock Star Widens Sexual Abuse Case Tied to BBC
articles.snippet: The sexual abuse scandal surrounding the late television host Jimmy Savile widened after the British police arrested Paul Gadd, who performed as Gary Glitter, in connection with the case.
articles.abstract: The sexual abuse scandal surrounding the late television host Jimmy Savile widened after the British police arrested Paul Gadd, who performed as Gary Glitter, in connection with the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sexual abuse scandal surrounding the late television host Jimmy Savile widened Sunday after the British police arrested a former pop star in connection with the case.

articles.headline: Sharp Warnings as Hurricane Churns In
articles.snippet: Forecasters said Hurricane Sandy would bring “life-threatening” flooding to areas of the East Coast and officials warned of days of disruptions as the storm swirled toward some of the nation’s most densely populated areas.
articles.abstract: Forecasters said Hurricane Sandy would bring “life-threatening” flooding to areas of the East Coast and officials warned of days of disruptions as the storm swirled toward some of the nation’s most densely populated areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy, a menacing monster of a storm that forecasters said would bring “life-threatening” flooding, churned toward some of the nation’s most densely populated areas on Sunday, prompting widespread evacuations and the shutdown of the New York City transit system.

articles.headline: News Corp. May Bid for Penguin for Publishing Spinoff
articles.snippet: News Corporation is exploring a cash bid for Pearson PLC’s Penguin book division, a step that could ignite a bidding war for Penguin as the publishing industry begins to move toward consolidation.
articles.abstract: News Corporation is exploring a cash bid for Pearson PLC’s Penguin book division, a step that could ignite a bidding war for Penguin as the publishing industry begins to move toward consolidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the parent company of HarperCollins, is exploring a cash bid for Pearson PLC’s Penguin book division, a step that could ignite a bidding war for Penguin as the publishing industry begins to move toward consolidation.

articles.headline: Disruptions: You Know You Can’t Live Without Apple’s Latest Glass Rectangle
articles.snippet: Each new Apple product makes the previous generation look old. How else could the company persuade people into replacing their perfectly fine iPhones, iPads and iPods year after year?
articles.abstract: Each new Apple product makes the previous generation look old. How else could the company persuade people into replacing their perfectly fine iPhones, iPads and iPods year after year?
articles.lead_paragraph: Philip W. Schiller, Apple’s vice president for marketing, strode across the stage of the California Theater in San Jose last week trumpeting the virtues of new Apple products. As he caressed the side of the latest iMac personal computer, he noted how thin it was — five millimeters, 80 percent thinner than the last one. Then he said, with an air of surprise, as if he’d just thought of it: “Isn’t it amazing how something new makes the previous thing instantly look old?”

articles.headline: Bracing for Storm, U.S. Stock Markets to Close
articles.snippet: All United States stock and options markets will close on Monday as Hurricane Sandy approaches, a decision made late Sunday night as Wall Street braced for the storm to barrel through the heart of the country’s financial center.
articles.abstract: All United States stock and options markets will close on Monday as Hurricane Sandy approaches, a decision made late Sunday night as Wall Street braced for the storm to barrel through the heart of the country’s financial center.
articles.lead_paragraph: 12:50 a.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: As Obama Accepts Offers, Late-Night Television Longs for Romney
articles.snippet: In the waning days of a close election, President Obama’s campaign has been betting that the late-night audience is worth courting, while Mitt Romney has declined all requests for appearances.
articles.abstract: In the waning days of a close election, President Obama’s campaign has been betting that the late-night audience is worth courting, while Mitt Romney has declined all requests for appearances.
articles.lead_paragraph: The week after the first presidential debate, with Mitt Romney riding a surge in the polls, Lorne Michaels believed he was close to achieving one of the perennial objectives of an election year for the celebrated television show he created and still produces, “Saturday Night Live.”

articles.headline: Silos Loom as Death Traps on American Farms
articles.snippet: Silos continue to be death traps for farmworkers — with many of the victims teenage boys — who are crushed or asphyxiated by grain in largely preventable accidents.
articles.abstract: Silos continue to be death traps for farmworkers — with many of the victims teenage boys — who are crushed or asphyxiated by grain in largely preventable accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING, Mich. — Tommy Osier, 18, a popular but indifferent student, was still a year from graduating from high school, and that was no sure thing. Farm work paid him $7.40 an hour, taught him discipline and gave him new skills. He had begun talking about making a life in farming.

articles.headline: Obama Is Even in TV Ad Race Despite PACs
articles.snippet: President Obama and his allies have reached audiences in roughly the same numbers as Mitt Romney and groups working to elect him.
articles.abstract: President Obama and his allies have reached audiences in roughly the same numbers as Mitt Romney and groups working to elect him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe the “super PACs” were not so super after all.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Nicholas Confessore and Sarah Cohen

articles.headline: Advertising Relearned for Mobile
articles.snippet: Advertising on devices like cellphones and tablets requires different approaches from advertising online, like taking advantage of the ability to track a consumer’s location.
articles.abstract: Advertising on devices like cellphones and tablets requires different approaches from advertising online, like taking advantage of the ability to track a consumer’s location.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Say you are in a strange city and need a hotel for the night. You pull out your phone, search for hotels on Google and see a nearby one listed at the top of the rankings, with a little phone icon that says, “Call.” You tap it, reach the hotel and ask for a room.

articles.headline: In Middle of a Messy Election, a Nightmare Makes Landfall
articles.snippet: Recounts, contested ballots, an Electoral College at odds with the popular vote: now adding to the campaigns’ potential horrors, a freakish storm may warp an election two years in the making.
articles.abstract: Recounts, contested ballots, an Electoral College at odds with the popular vote: now adding to the campaigns’ potential horrors, a freakish storm may warp an election two years in the making.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the dark of night, when they get what little sleep they get these days, the people running the campaigns for president have more than enough fodder for nightmares. Worse, come daybreak, they realize their worst fears may yet come true.

articles.headline: Chasing Armstrong With Truth
articles.snippet: Amid a conspiracy of silence about doping, a small group of dedicated cycling enthusiasts took to blogs and Twitter to dispute Lance Armstrong’s accomplishments.
articles.abstract: Amid a conspiracy of silence about doping, a small group of dedicated cycling enthusiasts took to blogs and Twitter to dispute Lance Armstrong’s accomplishments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Web is full of outliers who are constantly posting about vast conspiracies, advanced by powerful interests and enabled by the mainstream media. The truth, they say, is out there in plain sight.

articles.headline: Random House and Penguin Merger Creates Global Giant
articles.snippet: The deal between the media companies Bertelsmann, which owns Random House, and Pearson, which owns Penguin, might draw antitrust scrutiny.
articles.abstract: The deal between the media companies Bertelsmann, which owns Random House, and Pearson, which owns Penguin, might draw antitrust scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The book publishing industry is starting to get smaller in order to get stronger.
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Storm Barrels Through Region, Leaving Destructive Path
articles.snippet: The storm battered the mid-Atlantic region, its powerful gusts and storm surges causing once-in-a-generation flooding in coastal communities and knocking down trees and power lines.
articles.abstract: The storm battered the mid-Atlantic region, its powerful gusts and storm surges causing once-in-a-generation flooding in coastal communities and knocking down trees and power lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy battered the mid-Atlantic region on Monday, its powerful gusts and storm surges causing once-in-a-generation flooding in coastal communities, knocking down trees and power lines and leaving more than five million people — including a large swath of Manhattan — in the rain-soaked dark. At least seven deaths in the New York region were tied to the storm.
